stories.text:
Hello. I enjoy listening to history podcasts, but all I can find now is either about well-known topics (i.e discovery of America) or subtly reflecting the ideological opinions of the host.

I want to find something objective and original. The topics don't need to be too niche. Do you have any recommendations? Thanks.
stories.title: Ask HN: Any History Podcast Recommendations?
Research identifies potential role of ‘junk DNA’ sequence in aging, cancer
Tech giants to target attacker manifestos, far-right militias in database
Wildlife camera study is turned into a game
We got better at talking to users
BBC Olympics coverage misses events after loss of TV rights

stories.text:
I've worked through thousands of hours of math courses in my life and am now embarking on an amateur study of logical reasoning, mostly through puzzle books and the Logic course on Brilliant.org.

Although in each math and logic course it's easy to find explanations of the solutions, there is never any pedagogy surrounding the methodology to finding the solutions. The explanation of a problem solution given by a source often involves a key insight, but there's never an explanation of how to reliably come up with key insights!

I've looked for tips and tricks, but the answer appears to be either "do thousands of logic and math problems and gain an instinct for it" or "have any extremely high IQ".

Any thoughts?
stories.title: Ask HN: How Do You Learn to Solve Logic and Math Problems?
